Differential Diagnosis. Differentiated from
A. plicicollis
by the smaller size (ca. 1.20 mm vs. 1.34 mm ), the shallower pronotal impressions, with the midlongitudinal impression almost obsolete, and the shorter and sparser dorsal pubescence. The aedeagi of the two species differ in shapes of the distal part of the main piece, in both ventral and lateral views ( Figs. 212, 213 ).

Description . Size: holotype (length/width, mm): body (length to elytral apices) 1.20/0.56; head width 0.33; pronotum 0.29/0.52; elytra 0.60/0.56. Dorsum black except hyaline borders of prothorax transparent.

Eyes with moderately coarse, convex facets. Frons with deep impressions, borders of impressions rounded, smooth; clypeus with very few, very shallow punctures, almost impunctate; labrum anterior margin arcuate in both sexes.

Pronotal relief very smooth, with very sparse and very short indistinct setae; anterior and posterior transverse impressions very shallow, anterior contiguous with shallow transverse impression immediately behind anterior margin of lateral lobe; median longitudinal impression very shallow, barely perceptible, extended from anterior impression to ca. midlength of disc. Pronotum lateral hyaline borders very wide, extended from posterior to anterior angles, outer margin strongly arcuate; sides behind lateral lobes with conspicuous setae immediately above hyaline border; sides of lateral lobes without any or only few inconspicuous setae; anterior hyaline border moderately wide.

Elytra very smooth, ten seriate-punctate, punctures very small and very shallow, each with indistinct seta, very short, only slightly longer than width of puncture; lateral margin with setae in anterior 1/2.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 211.
Aulacochthebius perlaevis
, holotype, habitus dorsal and lateral.

subSubSection.paragraph: Males slightly smaller than females: males ca. 1.10â1.20 mm ; females ca. 1.16â1.28 mm .
Etymology . Named in reference to the very smooth dorsum.
Distribution . Rather widely distributed in Madagascar ( Fig. 305 ).

Remarks . In some specimens the aedeagus, when extracted by removing the abdominal terga, has the flagellum tightly looped in a "bundle." The flagellum of A. perlaevis is ribbon-like, and when uncoiled is totally flexible. The proximal end of the flagellum, which is inside the main-piece, appears to be "closed" and not connected with a duct. The gonopore might be at the distal end of the main-piece, not at the distal end of the flagellum. The flagellum, being ribbon-like, may serve as an adhesion device during copulation, not as a spermatophore transfer tube. The very small size of the aedeagus hinders a complete interpretation.
